bug.translation[0].definitions[0].defini: an illness that people catch very easily from each other but is not very serious
bug.translation[0].definitions[0].exampl: There’s a nasty bug going round (=that a lot of people have caught).
I picked up a bug last weekend.
He’s off work with a stomach bug.
bug.translation[0].definitions[2].defini: a fault in the system of instructions that operates a computer
bug.translation[0].definitions[3].defini: a small piece of electronic equipment for listening secretly to other people’s conversations
bug.translation[0].definitions[4].defini: a sudden strong interest in doing something
bug.translation[0].definitions[4].exampl: I had one flying lesson and immediately caught the bug (=became very interested in flying).
bug.translation[0].note_box[0].sections[: It was a really nasty bug.
He’s off school with a stomach bug.
We’ve all had a horrible flu bug.
The doctor says it’s just a 24-hour bug.
Two of us had a nasty bug on holiday.
Six out of ten travellers get a stomach bug abroad.
He seems to pick up every bug going.
A lot of staff are off because there’s a bug going round.
bug.translation[1].definitions[0].exampl: It just bugs me that I have to work so many extra hours for no extra money.
The baby’s crying is really bugging him.
bug.translation[1].definitions[1].defini: to put a bug (=small piece of electronic equipment) somewhere secretly in order to listen to conversations
bug.translation[1].definitions[1].exampl: Do you think the room is bugged?
bug.translation[2].definitions[0].defini: a Beetle  (=type of small Volkswagen car)
bug.translation[3].definitions[0].defini: a fault in the system of instructions that operates a computer
bug.translation[3].definitions[0].exampl: Custom-made software is often more reliable and has fewer ‘bugs’ or faults.
